posts.name: Teddy
posts.cooked: Recently, while browsing the Questnav Thread, I came across a post by @viggy96 suggesting the use of an Oak D camera equipped with the Spectacular AI Tracking Suite as an alternative to Questnav. This idea intrigued me, so I decided to experiment with my Oak D Lite camera. After a couple of days and a new USB cable, I managed to achieve decent AI tracking location capabilities with the Oak D Lite. However, it hasn't worked perfectly yet—I've noticed occasional jumps in position and moments when it drifts away. Additionally, the camera struggles with rotational movements and objects obstructing its view. While I suspect some of these issues might stem from configuration problems on my end, I also believe they could be related to the fact that the Oak D Lite isn't officially supported. Moving forward, my next step is to create a better visualizer since the existing ones from Spectacular AI aren't functioning well for me. If anyone has tips or questions, feel free to share!

link_counts.title: QuestNav: The Best Robot Pose Tracking System in FRC

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: I'm hopeful that this might provide a solution that is more compact, and easier to set up, and has fewer moving parts (setup-wise) than QuestNav. I have an Oak-D Pro W on the way.

posts.name: Teddy
posts.cooked: A slight update: I found a nice UI library that I should be able to set up fairly quickly, so I hope to post an initial prototype visualizer tomorrow.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: That one guy obsessed with programming

posts.name: Teddy
posts.cooked: Progress has been made, and the testing UI is now semi-functional. It’s quite janky since I put it together quickly in the morning under time pressure, but it mostly works. The source code is available here. The end of the GIF suggests that rotation is messing up the positioning, though I’m not sure why yet—I have a few theories. More updates will likely come soon. Also, it wasn’t designed specifically for the Oak model, so your Oak D Pro should work.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Much appreciated, I will test this as soon as I can.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Do you know if the necessary Python packages for this can be installed on the roboRIO? Was thinking that in actual deployment, it would be nice if the "host" computer was the roboRIO itself.

posts.name: Teddy
posts.cooked:
I placed a list of Python dependencies on the GitHub README.

Frankly, I think it would be unwise to attempt installing a package like that on the Roborio. The April Tag Competition is already costly enough, and even though I haven't tested my tool, I doubt it's computationally efficient.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: That one guy obsessed with programming

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Is it not offloaded to the OAK-D? Maybe it’s not offloaded on the Lite.

posts.name: rahilm
posts.cooked: I've been looking into the OAK-D as well to experiment with, but it seems like they don't recommend running any VSLAM processing on board with the current generation of products: VIO and SLAM. The next-gen OAK 4, which is coming out soon (but above the FRC price limit), does seem to have enough compute to perform this processing onboard.

posts.name: Teddy
posts.cooked: As far as I know, AI does not offload tasks to the Oak platform. The lightweight version, often referred to as "Lite," will not receive special treatment, as it is not officially supported by the developers. Additionally, according to Rahim, the creators of the Oak platform have stated that the current version of Oak is not sufficiently powerful to handle the required tasks effectively.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: That one guy obsessed with programming

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked: I wonder if dot projectors would be legal, or even viable, if this ever catches on. I’m not sure how resistant this sort of system is to external interference, but with 2-3 robots in a match having these on, I would guess pose estimation would already become dodgy for all of them.

link_counts.title: QuestNav: The Best Robot Pose Tracking System in FRC

posts.name: Teddy
posts.cooked:
More progress made! Most notably, I have fixed the rotation issue I was seeing with my oak d lite by setting the imu_to_camera matrix. Although the oak d lite is not supported, I want to give a shoutout to [oseiskar](https://github.com/oseiskar) for pointing me in the right direction.  

I have also been working on setting up apriltag support. However, I'm currently encountering an issue where it crashes upon detecting a tag and attempting to initialize the tracking system. I'm unsure about the cause. The stack trace suggests it might be related to libc or another component, though I can't confirm since the software involved is proprietary.  

Once I resolve the apriltag issues, I plan to rewrite my existing work to focus on nt4 support and improve its maintainability. Additionally, I won’t need my custom visualizer once I integrate advantagescope, which should simplify things.  

If anyone has insights into why the apriltag crashes, please share your thoughts.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: What does your AprilTag JSON look like?

posts.name: Teddy
posts.cooked: In the GitHub repository, I created a tool to convert Limelight .fmap files into Spectacular AI tags.json files. However, the actual issue seems unrelated to the loading of the tags themselves. Instead, the crash occurs when the system encounters a specific tag and attempts to initialize its tracking functionality.
